DataElement.preferredDefinition: Person; a human being._The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspects of an individual person._An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence._A domestic group, or a number of domestic groups linked through descent (demonstrated or stipulated) from a common ancestor, marriage, or adoption._A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._The aggregate of past events; the continuum of events occurring in succession leading from the past to the present; a record or narrative description of past events._The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of._A written or verbal account, representation, statement, or explanation of something._The words of something written.

Property.preferredName: Personal Attribute And Family Malignant Neoplasm History
Property.preferredDefinition: The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspects of an individual person.:An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.:Family; a domestic group, or a number of domestic groups linked through descent (demonstrated or stipulated) from a common ancestor, marriage, or adoption.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Concepts.definition: The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspects of an individual person.
An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.
A domestic group, or a number of domestic groups linked through descent (demonstrated or stipulated) from a common ancestor, marriage, or adoption.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
The aggregate of past events; the continuum of events occurring in succession leading from the past to the present; a record or narrative description of past events.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
